Page 2.
duplicate
"Poker Patience".
There was no bomb raids as the bad weather
continued.
Sunday A.M. Oct. 31st. Yesterday was also a bad day - therefore a good
day.
Our Meneging Director arrived from Henkow having been unable to join us
Friday because
the airplane schedule was cancelled that day account weather.
Vie
had a session with him - went to dinner at the International Club where most of the
foreigners remaining in Nanking congregate every Saturday night to make a little
whoopie up to curfew time at 11 P.M.
I met many old friends there and had a fine
time.
There was only one woman present - a French girl who arrived here a few
weeks ago as a volunteer nurse -
fell in love with a French newspaper o respondes
and was married night before last.
The whole town turned out for the wedding.
Women in Nanking are so scarce that whenever
you see
one you stemp your hand as
the kids do when they see a white horse.
About 80% of the foreign population of
Nanking has
One.
I had a long talk with Mr. Holm a good friend of ours who used to be Posta
Commissioner at Chungking.
He has resigned and is keen on returning with Mrs.
to his "home"
in Copenhagen after thirty years in China.
I wonder if they won't
soon went to
come back.
â‚¬ to cood baa beluter cinese coet proved rent free vy the post
for instance, at Chungking Mr. Holm was a real per-
Office, surrounded by
a lovely garden.
He travelled to work in a grand
fitted out like a small
throne, borne by bur uniformed chair coolies.
No. l boy who ran the house and looked after every detail from food to
pressing
shining his shoes.
Several coolies were at his beck and call to run
Three gardners
cared for his
though it were
Later - Sunday night - rain and low ceiling all day.
Had long conference
with Vice-Minister of Communications which lasted all morning and accomplished
nothing.
Very
discouraging,
Lunch with lir. Pook and Mr. Johnson also d inner -
much conversation but no results.
Americen attitude very sympathetic and helpfu?
Chinese very unsympathetic and non cooperative.
some Chinese officials can be
unbelievably dull and stupid. Our friend of today's onference seems intent only
on immediate necessities
to
the exclusion of all else. Hope for better luck to-
morrow.
We have been here now two and one half days with no air attack which probably
means a strong one or more tomorrow, unless of course this weather continues.
is an air of expectancy in lanking, a sort of indefinite
tenseness which must get
on everyones' nerves sooner or later.
Possibly they get used to it and probably
I would too but frenkly I'll be glad to get away.
Will send this letter by Tuesdey's plane to Hankow with the hope that it
will catch Eurasia to Hongkong Wednesdey and the Clipper to Manila on Thursday.
Next installment will B llow later.
We
get little news here except about the Shanghai front end even that is
mixed with all sorts of wild rumors.
Weren't the Japs showing their real nature
when they fired at the "doomed battled on"
when they evacueted that warehouse and
surrendered
to the British for internment?
Those dirty little Japs haven't any
decent traits.
Why didn't they cease firing and give those Chinese
a rousing cheer
when they evacuated. That would have been sporting - but not at all Japanose.
As ever
Harold
